sen.j: 市河 米庵（いちかわ べいあん、安永8年9月16日 (旧暦)（1779年） - 安政5年7月18日 (旧暦)（1858年8月26日））は、江戸時代後期の日本の書家、漢詩人。
sen.e: Beian ICHIKAWA (Sep 16, 1779 - Aug 26, 1858) was a calligrapher and poet of the latter Edo period.
Beian ICHIKAWA (September 16, 1779 - August 26, 1858) was a Japanese calligrapher and kanshi (Chinese-style poems) poet of the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: 形式・用語・表現を修正しました
sen.e: Beian ICHIKAWA (October 25, 1779 - August 26, 1858) was a Japanese calligrapher and kanshi (Chinese-style poems) poet of the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ歴に変更しました。

sen.j: 名前は三亥、字は孔陽、号は米庵のほかに楽斎・百筆斎・亦顛道人・小山林堂・金洞山人・金羽山人・西野子など。
sen.e: His given name was 三亥 and pen name 孔陽 and, besides being called 'Beian` he was also known as 楽斎・百筆斎・亦顛道人・小山林堂・金洞山人・金羽山人・西野子 etc.

His given name was Sangai and Chinese courtesy name was Koyo and, besides being called Beian, his pen names included: Rakusai ("楽斎"), Hyakuhitsusai ("百筆斎"), Ekiten (or Yakuten or Mataten) dojin ("亦顛道人"), Shosanrindo (or Koyamarindo or Oyamarindo or Kosanrindo, written as "小山林堂"), Kinto-sanjin ("金洞山人"), Kin-u-sanjin ("金羽山人") and Seiyashi ("西野子").
sen.cmt: 人名読み（推測による）を修正しました。なお、原文中のリンク先表示を削除しました。
sen.e: His given name was Sangai and Chinese courtesy name was Koyo and, besides being called Beian, his pen names included: Rakusai ("楽斎"), Hyakuhitsusai ("百筆斎"), Ekiten (or Yakuten or Mataten) dojin ("亦顛道人"), Shosanrindo (or Koyamarindo or Oyamarindo or Kosanrindo, written as "小山林堂"), Kinto-sanjin ("金洞山人"), Kin-u-sanjin ("金羽山人") and Seiyashi ("西野子").

sen.j: 通称は小左衛門。
sen.e: His common name was Gozaemon.
His common name was Kozaemon.
sen.cmt: 人名読み（推測による）を修正しました
sen.e: His common name was Kozaemon.

sen.j: 漢詩の市河寛斎の長子。
sen.e: He was the eldest son of the Chinese-style poet Kansai ICHIKAWA.
Beian was the eldest son of the kanshi poet Kansai ICHIKAWA.
sen.cmt: 用語を修正しました。曖昧さ回避のため主語を具体的にしました
sen.e: Beian was the eldest son of the kanshi poet Kansai ICHIKAWA.

sen.j: 安永8年（1779年）、己亥九月、亥の日、亥の刻に江戸日本橋 (東京都中央区)桶町に生まれたので三亥と名付けられた。
sen.e: Bean's was given the birth name 三亥 to reflect the fact that the same Japanese Character `亥` appeared (in the zodiac month, day and hour) 3 times (hence the use of character for three `三`) at the time of his birth.

Beian was given the birth name Sangai (which was written as "三亥" in Japanese) to reflect the fact that the same Japanese Character "亥" appeared three times at the time of his birth, i.e. in the zodiac month, day and hour, hence the use of character for three "三."
sen.cmt: 用語・表現・形式を修正しました
sen.e: Beian was given the birth name Sangai (which was written as "三亥" in Japanese) to reflect the fact that the same Japanese Character "亥" appeared three times at the time of his birth, i.e. in the zodiac month, day and hour, hence the use of character for three "三."

sen.j: 父 寛斎や林述斎・柴野栗山に師事し、書は長崎に遊学し清国の胡兆新に学ぶ。
sen.e: Beian studied under his father Kansai as well as from Ritsuzan SHIBANO, traveled to Nagasaki to learn penmanship studying under the Tang master 胡兆新.

He studied under his father Kansai as well as from Jussai HAYASHI and Ritsuzan SHIBANO, and in terms of Japanese calligraphy he traveled to Nagasaki to learn penmanship studying under a Qing master named HU Zhaoxin (Choshin KO in Japanese, written as "胡兆新").
sen.cmt: 用語・表現・形式を修正しました
sen.e: He studied under his father Kansai as well as from Jussai HAYASHI and Ritsuzan SHIBANO, and in terms of Japanese calligraphy he traveled to Nagasaki to learn penmanship studying under a Qing master named HU Zhaoxin (Choshin KO in Japanese, written as "胡兆新").

sen.j: その後、北宋代の書家・米芾や唐代の書家・顔真卿らの書を敬慕しその筆法を研鑽する。
sen.e: Subsequently, Beian came to deeply respect the work of the Qing calligraphers Mi Fei (米芾), Yan Zhenqing (顔真卿) and others and devoted himself to studying their style of penmanship.

Subsequently, Beian came to deeply respect the works of Beisong-dynasty calligrapher MI Fei (or MI Fu, or Futsu BEI in Japanese, written as "米芾"), and Tang-dynasty calligrapher YAN Zhenqing (Shinkei GAN in Japanese, written as "顔真卿") and others, and devoted himself to studying their styles of penmanship.
sen.cmt: 原文中、史実に基づいて次の修正を加えた上、再訳出しました：「宋代」→「北宋代」、「唐代の書家・」。根拠：http://kotobank.jp/word/%E7%B1%B3%E3%81%B5%E3%81%A4、http://kotobank.jp/word/%E9%A1%94%E7%9C%9F%E5%8D%BF
sen.e: Subsequently, Beian came to deeply respect the works of Beisong-dynasty calligrapher MI Fei (or MI Fu, or Futsu BEI in Japanese, written as "米芾"), and Tang-dynasty calligrapher YAN Zhenqing (Shinkei GAN in Japanese, written as "顔真卿") and others, and devoted himself to studying their styles of penmanship.

sen.j: 米庵という号は米芾に因んだ。
sen.e: The name `Beian` is often confused with `Mi Fei`.
The pen name Beian ("米庵") was named after Mi Fei ("米芾").
sen.cmt: 形式・用語・表現を修正しました
sen.e: The pen name Beian ("米庵") was named after Mi Fei ("米芾").

sen.j: 隷書・楷書を得意とし、寛政11年（1799年）、20歳の時に書塾 小山林堂を開いた。
sen.e: Beian was noted for his skill in angular (reisho) and square/block (kaisho) styled calligraphy and in 1799 at 20 years of age he opened a calligraphy school called 小山林堂.

Beian was noted for his skill in demotic semi-square styled (reisho) and standard or square styled (kaisho) calligraphy, and in 1799, at the age of 20 he opened a private calligraphy school called Shosanrindo ("小山林堂").
sen.cmt: 小山林堂の読み不明につき、類推によります。用語・表現を修正しました
sen.e: Beian was noted for his skill in demotic semi-square styled (reisho) and standard or square styled (kaisho) calligraphy, and in 1799, at the age of 20 he opened a private calligraphy school called Shosanrindo ("小山林堂").

sen.j: その後、和泉橋藤堂候西門前に大きな屋敷を構え、門人は延べ5千人に達したという。
sen.e: Later, he built up a large estate at 和泉橋藤堂氏西門前 and was said to have had over 5,000 pupils.
Later, he built up a large estate in front of the west gate of the mansion of Lord Todo at Izumibashi, and is said to have had over a total of 5,000 pupils.
sen.cmt: 原文中のリンク先表示を、対応wikiサイトに準じて修正しました。未訳部分を訳出しました。表現を修正しました。
sen.e: Later, he built up a large estate in front of the west gate of the mansion of Lord Todo at Izumibashi, and is said to have had over a total of 5,000 pupils.

sen.j: 尾張徳川、津藤堂、徳山毛利、鯖江間部などの大名にも指南を行った。
sen.e: Even the Daimyo (feudal lords) of the Owari, Tsu, Tokuyama and Sabae domains etc sought out instruction.
He gave lessons even to daimyo (feudal lords) such as Owari-Tokugawa clan, Tsu-Todo clan, Tokuyama-Mori clan and Sabae-Manabe clan.
sen.cmt: 原文中のリンク先表示を対応wikiサイトに準じて修正のうえ、再訳出しました。用語・表現を修正しました
sen.e: He gave lessons even to daimyo (feudal lords) such as Owari-Tokugawa clan, Tsu-Todo clan, Tokuyama-Mori clan and Sabae-Manabe clan.

sen.j: 書の流派である江戸唐様派の大家。
sen.e: He was a distinguished member of the Edo-Chinese Tang style school of calligraphy.
He was a distinguished member of the Edo karayo-ha school (literally, Edo Tang Chinese style school) of calligraphy.
He was a distinguished member of the Edo karayo-ha school (literally, Edo Tang Chinese style school) of calligraphy.

sen.j: 同じく江戸で門戸を張った巻菱湖（1777-1843）、京都の貫名海屋（1778-1863）とともに幕末の三筆に数えられる。
sen.e: Similarly, the calligrapher Ryoko MAKI (1777-1843) opened his doors in Edo, as did Kaio NUKINA (1778-1863) in Kyoto and together they are counted as the 3 major calligraphers of the Bakumatsu (shogunate) era.

Like Beian, a calligrapher named Ryoko MAKI (1777-1843) opened his doors in Edo, as did Kaioku NUKINA (1778-1863) in Kyoto, and together they are counted as the three major calligraphers of the Bakumatsu (last years of shogunate) era.
sen.cmt: 表現・用語・人名を修正しました
sen.e: Like Beian, a calligrapher named Ryoko MAKI (1777-1843) opened his doors in Edo, as did Kaioku NUKINA (1778-1863) in Kyoto, and together they are counted as the three major calligraphers of the Bakumatsu (last years of shogunate) era.

sen.j: 文化 (元号)8年（1811年）に富山藩に仕えたが、文政4年（1821年）に家禄300石をもって加賀藩前田氏に仕え、江戸と金沢を往復し指導に当たった。
sen.e: In 1811 Beian served the Toyama domain however, in 1821 he went to serve the Maeda Clan in the Kaga domain for an annual stipend of 300 koku and commuted between Kanazawa and Edo to teach.
In 1811, Beian served Toyama Domain, but in 1821, he went to serve the Maeda Clan of Kaga Domain for an annual stipend of 300 koku and commuted between Kanazawa and Edo to teach.

sen.e: In 1811, Beian served Toyama Domain, but in 1821, he went to serve the Maeda Clan of Kaga Domain for an annual stipend of 300 koku and commuted between Kanazawa and Edo to teach.

sen.j: 余技に篆刻を嗜み、印譜『爽軒試銕』がある。
sen.e: He became skillful in his hobby of making seals and compiled a book about seals entitled `爽軒試銕`.
He became skillful in his hobby of making seals and compiled an inpu (book about seals) titled "Soken shitetsu."

sen.j: 文房四宝に凝り唐晋の書画の蒐蔵と研究で知られる。
sen.e: Beian was known for his collection and study of the 4 calligraphy implements (brush, ink stone, ink stick & paper) and later Tang dynasty calligraphy.

Beian reveled in his love of bunbo shiho (literally, the four treasures of the study, referring to calligraphy implements: brush, ink stone, ink stick and paper) and was known for his collection and study of calligraphic works and paintings of Tang and Jin dynasties.

sen.e: Beian reveled in his love of bunbo shiho (literally, the four treasures of the study, referring to calligraphy implements: brush, ink stone, ink stick and paper) and was known for his collection and study of calligraphic works and paintings of Tang and Jin dynasties.

sen.j: また煎茶を嗜み、松井釣古の主人であった加賀屋清兵衛に楓川亭と命名している。
sen.e: Beian had an appreciation for sencha (mid-grade green tea) and gave a tea shop its name.
Further, Beian had an appreciation for sencha (mid-grade green tea) and gave Seibei KAGAYA, who owned Matsui Choko ("松井釣古"), a pen name Fusentei.

sen.j: 『米庵墨談』など多数の著述がある。
sen.e: Beian wrote a number of books including `墨談` (lit. Beian`s Ink Talk).
Beian wrote a number of books including "Beian Bokudan" (literally, Beian's Ink Talk).

sen.j: 継子に恵まれずはじめ稲毛屋山の子市河恭斎（きょうさい、1796 - 1833）を養子に迎えるが夭折してしまい、次いで市河遂庵（いちかわ すいあん、1804 - 1884）を迎えた。
sen.e: Having no children, he adopted Okuzan INAGE`s child (Kyosai ICHIKAWA (1796 - 1833)) however, Kyosai died prematurely and subsequently Suian ICHIKAWA (1804 - 1884) was adopted.
Having no heir, he adopted Okuzan INAGE's son who became Kyosai ICHIKAWA (1796-1833), but Kyosai died prematurely and subsequently, Suian ICHIKAWA (1804-1884) was adopted.

sen.j: しかし、米庵が60歳のときに長子、市河万庵（いちかわ まんあん、1838 - 1907）を授かる。
sen.e: However, when Beian was 60 years old he was blessed with a son: Manan ICHIKAWA (1838 - 1907).
However, when Beian was 60 years old, he was blessed with a son: Manan ICHIKAWA (1838-1907).
